content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider the following:

1. In this game, choosing R always gives a higher payoff when the opponent chooses B (40$ vs 20$). However, if both players choose R, they earn less than if they chose B (45$ vs 20$).

2. Since the opponent is anonymous, I have no information about their strategy. Therefore, I cannot predict with certainty whether they will choose R or B more often.

3. If I assume that my opponent is rational and wants to maximize their earnings, they would likely choose the option that earns them the most in each round. Given the payoff structure, they would prefer R when I choose B and vice versa. However, this strategy does not guarantee the highest average earnings for both players because choosing R twice results in no earnings for both (0$ total).

4. To maximize my earnings, I should consider a mixed strategy where I don't always choose the same option. A possible strategy could be to choose R approximately 56% of the time (56 out of 100 rounds) and B the remaining 44%. This way, if my opponent follows a similar mixed strategy, we would both earn more than if we chose either R or B exclusively.

5. The game has 75 rounds instead of 100, which gives an advantage to the R strategy because it guarantees higher payoffs when the opponent chooses B in specific rounds (40$ vs 20$). However, considering that my opponent is likely to follow a mixed strategy as well, choosing R exclusively might not be beneficial due to potential losses from choosing R twice.

6. Given these factors, I would still lean toward a slightly R-biased strategy, perhaps choosing R around 58% of the time (44 out of 75 rounds) and B the rest. This choice would give me an expected earnings of approximately 31.2$ per round on average, while sticking to either R or B exclusively might result in lower average earnings.

My choice: {R} but with a slight preference toward choosing R around 58% of the time.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this specific case, since both me and my opponent chose R in the previous round, we earned 45$ each. If we assume that our opponents' strategy follows a mixed approach as well (as rational players would), they might choose R again to take advantage of the higher payoff when I choose B. However, given that I chose R in the last round, my opponent now has an incentive to switch their strategy and choose B in this round to maximize their earnings.

In the next round, considering a mixed strategy, I would choose R approximately 58% of the time (44 out of 74 remaining rounds) and B the rest (30 out of 74). This way, if my opponent follows a similar mixed strategy, we can both earn more on average.
